text: on November fifth Mayor Bloomberg
revealed a projected 4 billion dollar
gap in new york city's budget for 2009
2010 to begin to make up the difference
bloomberg announced a number of
cost-cutting measures including
canceling January's police academy in
laying off several thousand city
employees but what about something as
simple as turning off the lights
lighting accounts for nearly a quarter
of the energy use in new york city's
buildings and yet after closing time
many lights simply stay on these are
city run buildings on a monday night
just before midnight
leaving the lights on at city buildings
is like watering the sidewalks City Hall
Park nearly 800 million dollars is spent
every year keeping city-run buildings
lit heated and cooled under the mayor's
long-term plan YC proposal energy use
and buildings will be cut using compact
fluorescent lighting motion sensor
technology and daylight dimming controls
many of these technologies require an
upfront cost and so are unlikely to be
part of the short-term budget balance
but it doesn't cost much to encourage
city employees and cleaning crews to
turn off the lights when they leave work
it may not be the most exciting way to
green the city but nationwide it's
estimated that over one and a half
billion dollars is wasted every year
unlike that isn't doing anyone any good
either lighting unused rooms or just
floating up into outer space
at a time when migrating birds are
pulled off course by bright urban light
domes and when millions of school kids
can hardly make out the Big Dipper it's
worth remembering that cities like
Chicago Tucson and Toronto have already
started to rain in their lights and as
the new president elect has often
pointed out civic responsibility begins
with personal responsibility if Mayor
Bloomberg can work with city employees
to cut energy use it will be easier for
him to ask all of us to follow suit
you
